Award.AbstractNarration: CAREER: Symbolic-Numeric Constraint-Based Solutions for Real-World Scientific Problems PI:Martine Ceberio, University of Texas at El Paso ABSTRACT Numerical constraint solving (NCS) techniques have proven to be efficient to solve real problems ranging from electronic circuit to aircraft design. Yet they are under-utilized. The lack of user support of the solvers can partly explain this, but most importantly NCS techniques have isolated themselves into a jargon (constraints) and a schema (propagation/reduction) that disconnect them, respectively, from real problems and real needs (e.g., scalability, flexibility, and distributivity). The goal of this career plan is to make NCS better adapted to real-world needs while making it more accessible. In order to achieve the goal, this project will concentrate on theory and algorithms at the crux of the efficiency, reliability, and distributivity aspects of problemsolving techniques. In particular, the following research objectives will be pursued: RO1 To open NCS to novel techniques, improving scalability and reliability. The research will be oriented towards designing new algorithms that lie between local consistency techniques and global constraints: symbolic-numeric approaches will be studied from the theoretical point of view, and algorithms will be developed and embedded in a new solving toolbox; RO2 To assist users facing over-constrained problems. New methods based on the topology of the search space, in terms of satisfaction of the constraints, will be designed to provide users with alternative solutions; and RO3 To extend the distributed use of NCS to reflect the emerging networked social structure. The structures of social groups and their potential to support distributed systems will be studied, resulting in new and more complete algorithms for distributing constraints. The results of the research objectives will feed into the work carried out to pursue our education objectives: EO1: to enhance the problem-solving skills and interest in advanced studies for 8-16 students; and EO2: to enhance the participation ofwomen and Hispanics in computing. Intellectual Merit. The success of the Career project will contribute to the NCS and decisionmaking body of knowledge. The proposed work will advance knowledge about: i. NCS algorithms: Along with theoretical results about the quality of the solution, the proposed work will address the noise in solution sets, as well as continuums of solutions; ii. Soft constraints: By developing decision algorithms for over-constrained problems, it will be possible to (semi-)autonomously determine the most relevant soft constraints scheme to solve the original problem; iii. Constraints distribution over different social groups structures: the expected communication algorithms will combine theory from speculative constraints with frameworks of social structures to improve the time to solution of given constraints. Broader Impacts. The project will result in a new Matlab toolbox, expected to enhance the way users approach problem solving and appeal to more users, in particular the Matlab community. The progress and results of the project will be disseminated through the PIs constraintsolving.com website, widely accessed by various communities. Moreover, the PI holds a CoProD workshop that annually brings together NCS researchers and practitioners. The project will take place at UTEP, an institution with more than 75% Hispanic citizens and a leader in the education and advancement of Hispanics. With UTEPs infrastructure and the proposed educational activities, the project will train a new generation of diverse computer scientists with strong problem-solving skills. It will also result in new constraint-based courses, including material that can contribute to a textbook on NCS that will have impact beyond UTEP. Workshops and constraint-oriented hands-on activities will be offered at one middle-school and three high-schools, one of which is a women-only high-school, with potential to inspire students to engage in computing disciplines. It is expected that over 450 students will be involved in outreach activities over the course of the grant.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project, titled CAREER: Symbolic-Numeric Constraint-Based Solutions for Real-World Scientific Problems, aimed to advance knowledge about and the use of Numerical Constraint Solving algorithms. Indeed, many real-life problems are expressed in terms of numerical constraints (possibly along with the goal to maximize or minimize some quantity) so many applications could benefit from scientific and computing advances in the area of numerical constraint solving (NCS). However, there was a gap between the advances in this area and the lack of awareness about such advances, resulting in the lack of use of numerical constraint solving techniques in applications that matter.

To achieve a broader use of NCS techniques, it was necessary to take a look at what were barriers to their use. One of them was the computing burden of such techniques and their possible lack of flexibility. Another one was the lack of awareness that such techniques existed.

 

In this project, we worked on both identified barriers. We developed new solving techniques for numerical constraint problems as well as for optimization problems (when, in addition to requirements to be met, a problem also comes along with some objective to maximize or minimize). In particular, we developed a solver based on speculative computations, meant to speed up computations by making bets on best “solutions” and we made it available to the public by packaging it and uploading it as an executable for Windows and Mac machines. We developed techniques that allow solving very large constraint problems in a very limited time: we used the idea of reduced-order modeling and adapted it to continuous problems with uncertainty, to guarantee results (robust to computer rounding errors and to model uncertainty).

To address the lack of awareness about NCS techniques, we designed and maintained a website, constraintsolving.com, whose aim is to disseminate work, including software packages and tutorials, related to NCS techniques. This website has drawn significant attention over the years (it has existed since the first year of the project). In addition to that, we created and organized every year an annual international workshop, CoProD, for Constraint Programming and Decision Making, which annually aims to draw together two main and usually disjoint communities: domain scientists, and optimization and NCS researchers. And of course, many research articles and presentations have resulted from this project, allowing the contributions to be disseminated to wider audiences.

 

All of this work, however scientifically important, has always been with the aim to contribute to the training of students, the preparation of the next generation of computer scientists and engineers. From the research point of view only, it has allowed to train many students: over 50 undergraduate students, and 10 graduate students have been exposed to this project, either directly or because of their participation in the PI’s research lab. On a broader scale, during the lifetime of this project, undergraduate students at the University of Texas at El Paso (UTEP) were exposed to the findings of the project through courses taught as special topics and through modules taught in Artificial Intelligence and other relevant courses at UTEP. In addition, the creation of a problem-solving club in computer science helped the PI reach out to more students from UTEP and to train them to modeling and solving, which are essential elements of NCS techniques. However, the pipeline of the future generation of professionals in computing does not reside at the college level only, so we reached out to K-12 schools of El Paso. Focusing our efforts on training students to the techniques of problem solving in general and to research, we have invited and hosted high-school intern students every summer in the PI’s research lab since 2010 and we have designed teaching summer-camp modules for middle- and high-school students. In this manner, we were able to reach out to several hundreds of middle- and high-school students. Several of them are now students in computer science or other engineering disciplines at UTEP. It is important to note that these efforts were often in synergy with other outreach efforts of the PI to lead the local NCWIT Aspirations in Computing program in El Paso. As a result, emphasis in most of the above efforts was put on the outreach to and recruitment of women in computing. Over the lifetime of the project, such efforts allowed the PI to provide one-on-one mentoring to about 30 high-school young women (as interns to her research lab and/or students of the El Paso area seeking guidance and mentoring in computing).
